full_title_en: Glasgow-Imrie Criteria for Severity of Acute Pancreatitis
medium_description_en: Determines severity of pancreatitis based on 8 laboratory values.
instructions_en: These criteria are traditionally scored with values at 48 hours after admission.

seo.meta_description_en: The Glasgow-Imrie Criteria for Acute Pancreatitis determines severity of pancreatitis based on 8 laboratory values.
seo.keywords_en: Glasgow, pancreatitis, panc, imrie, imrie score, imrie scoring system, imrie pancreatitis, glasgow pancreatitis, glasgow score, acute pancreatitis,

how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• The Glasgow-Imrie Criteria predict severity of pancreatitis but at 48 hours after admission.
  • A severe pancreatitis episode involved death, need for surgery or complications from pancreatitis.

Points to keep in mind:

  • The lab values are usually evaluated at 48 hours after admission, not upon admission.
  • This study was developed in the 1980s, prior to significant advances in the treatment and evaluation of pancreatitis, including advanced imaging.
how_to_use.why_use_en: Predicting severity, mortality, and need for therapies in pancreatitis is notoriously difficult and multifactorial. Using a scoring system may help standardize treatment and allow for targeting patients in greatest danger.

next_steps.advice_en: The Glasgow-Imrie Criteria are comparable to the Ranson's criteria, but both have a disadvantage of requiring a 48 hours delay before they can be appropriately applied. Studies have suggested a binary cutoff at ≥3 as suggesting a significant increase in likelihood of severe pancreatitis.
next_steps.management_en: Local management algorithms using the criteria have been published; none are validated.
next_steps.critical_actions_en: The Glasgow-Imrie Criteria require using peak laboratory values and can be appropriately applied only at 48 hours after admission.

about.formula_en:
Addition of selected points.

Useful mnemonic: PANCREAS

  • PaO2< 7.9kPa
  • Age > 55 years
  • Neutrophils (WBC > 15 x 10⁹/L)
  • Calcium < 2 mmol/L
  • Renal function: Urea > 16 mmol/L
  • Enzymes LDH > 600 IU/L
  • Albumin < 32 g/L (serum)
  • Sugar (blood glucose) > 10 mmol/L

creator_info.about_en: Clem W. Imrie, MD, is a retired professor of surgery, formerly working at the Glasgow Royal Infirmary. He has received numerous awards for his research and practice involving pancreatitis, most recently the George E. Palade Prize of the International Association of Pancreatology. His research interests include the diagnosis, treatment and surgical techniques of Pancreato Biliary surgery.
